item.title: Building a Second Brain
item.description: Summary Your ‘second brain’ is a lifelong system serving as a knowledge repository, a place to manage the projects that are important in your life, and a place to steward your personal growth.

item.title: Clean Code
item.description: TODO. Coupling Coupling describes how dependent one thing is on another. In object-oriented programming, it refers to how dependent one class is on another.

item.title: Deep Work
item.description: These ideas are sourced from Cal Newport’s ‘Deep Work’ book, my personal observations about when I am most effective in complex technical endeavours and the blogs of some of the most effective software engineers out there.

item.title: Discipline is Destiny

item.title: Don't Make Me Think
item.description: “The human brain’s capacity doesn’t change from one year to the next, so the insights from studying human behaviour have a very long shelf life.

item.title: Four Thousand Weeks
item.description: ðŸ’Ž Embrace finitude, it’s what gives time and experience meaning and value. The fact that you exist is a cosmic miracle, and we always tend to forget that we had no right to exist, let alone to have things go our way all the time.

item.title: Fundamentals of Software Architecture
item.description: Everything in software architecture is a trade-off â€” First Law of Software Architecture The software engineering ecosystem is constantly in flux as the result of new technologies, capabilities and changing assumptions.

item.title: How Not to Die
item.description: âš There is a lot of criticism directed to the claims made in this book, and counter-studies against those claims. Remember to be skeptical but open-minded to arguments made for and against Greger’s recommendations.

item.title: Lying
item.description: ðŸ’Ž Obey the precept uncompromisingly: never tell lies. ðŸ’Ž White lies, when unpacked, are never the compassionate option. Telling a white lie denies the person their autonomy to act on true information and is a failure of friendship.

item.title: Man's Search For Meaning
item.description: ðŸ’Ž It is always possible to be a good man in the most hellish of conditions, and to have the strength of character to give away your last ration despite suffering extreme starvation.

item.title: Meditations
item.description: ðŸ’Ž It is irrational to hate people or vilify people for wrongdoing. They’re people to sympathise with because they’ve forgotten or have never experienced the beauty in goodness.

item.title: Pragmatic Programmer
item.description: Being a Craftsman Care about your craft. Never run on auto-pilot. Constantly be thinking and critiquing your work in real time.

item.title: Property Investing For Dummies
item.description: “Although the basic principles of property investment are similar the world over, fundamental differences exist between Australia and the United States that affect investment strategies, the seeds of which are sown in the vastly different tax treatments meted out to property investments in each country.

item.title: Reading
item.description: Favourites: Man’s Search for Meaning by Viktor Frankl. Deep Work by Cal Newport. Meditations by Marcus Aurelius (Hays translation). Lying by Sam Harris.

item.title: Rich Dad Poor Dad
item.description: The main takeaway for me is that you must be financially literate and ruthlessly invest in your knowledge. This means being bold and learning things that you dislike or are fearful of such as sales, negotiation, public speaking, leadership, etc.

item.title: Spark
item.description: Exercise is the single most powerful tool you have to optimise your brain function. This book has convinced me to always fit aerobic exercise and weight training into every day, unconditionally.

item.description: Samatha â€” tranquility Vipassana â€” insight Samadhi â€” stable attention Sati â€” mindfulness Meditation is the art of fully conscious living.
